text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Vietnam and Canada have signed a framework agreement on cooperation on nuclear power technology.

-- The government is to crack down on the misuse of telecommunications and postal facilities, including the use of unauthorized radio frequencies, and damage to or making unlawful use of telecommunication network.
-- Thirty-nine Ho Chi Minh City candidates for the upcoming National Assembly elections begin their campaigning on Thursday.
-- The Morgan Stanley group and Vietnam Insurance Corporation plan to set up a $100 million investmnet fund.
-- U.S State Secretary Madeleine Albright will take part in a cornerstone-laying ceremony for a U.S Consulate in Ho Chi Minh City on June 28.
-- Communist Party General Secretary Do Muoi has called for greater efforts to help war-martyrs' families and war invalids, including soldiers suffering from the effects of agent orange.
-- Vietnam's Foreign Ministry says British-Hong Kong authorities are responsible for delays in the repatriation of boatpeople from Hong Kong camps.
-- Senior Politburo member Lt-General Le Kha Phieu has said that more action is needed to help children, and the Party would have to bear responsibility for inadequate efforts to protect them.
-- Hanoi is completing the second phase of a $226.5 million project to improve the city's electricity network.
-- Ho Chi Minh City's Party Committee is stepping up the fight against corruption.
-- The Ministry of Trade reported an estimated trade deficit of $1.433 billion in the first half of 1997.
